prompt: For EIS income tax relief, what is the maximum amount of qualifying subscriptions that can attract relief in a tax year, and at what rate (ignoring the ‘lower of’ liability cap)?
explanation: EIS income tax relief is a tax reducer on subscriptions up to £1,000,000 in a tax year at 30% (subject to being capped by the individual’s income tax liability). Distractors: B[same_family], C[threshold_swap], D[exception_as_rule], E[threshold_swap].

prompt: An individual subscribed for qualifying EIS shares and claimed EIS income tax relief at 30%. The shares are later sold at a loss. How is the amount of income tax relief withdrawn (per your notes)?
option_a: A. Relief withdrawn equals proceeds × 30% (or original % relief if lower)
option_b: B. Relief withdrawn equals cost × 30% (or original % relief if lower)
option_c: C. All income tax relief is withdrawn on any disposal, regardless of proceeds
option_d: D. No income tax relief is withdrawn if the shares are sold at a loss
option_e: E. Relief withdrawn equals gain × 30% (or original % relief if lower)
explanation: Where EIS shares are sold at a loss, your notes state the amount withdrawn is proceeds × 30% (or the original % relief if lower). Distractors: B[term_confusion], C[exception_as_rule], D[wrong_direction], E[term_confusion].

prompt: Which statement correctly describes the CGT/dividend position for VCT shares (per your notes)?
option_a: A. VCT dividends are tax-free and gains on disposal (new issues or secondary purchases) are exempt; losses are not allowable
option_b: B. VCT dividends are taxed normally and only gains on new issues are exempt; losses are allowable
option_c: C. VCT dividends are tax-free but gains are only exempt if shares are held for 3 years; losses are allowable
option_d: D. VCT dividends are taxed normally but gains are exempt with no minimum holding period; losses are allowable
option_e: E. VCT dividends are tax-free but gains are only exempt if shares are held for 5 years; losses are not allowable
explanation: Your notes: VCT dividend income is tax-free; gains on disposal of both secondary purchases and new issues are exempt from CGT; losses are not allowable; no minimum holding period is required for this CGT treatment. Distractors: B[same_family], C[threshold_swap], D[term_confusion], E[threshold_swap].

prompt: Which is the key tax/NIC driver for using a personal service company (PSC) rather than being a normal employee?
option_a: A. More generous expense deduction rules and lower NIC rates can apply to self-employment
option_b: B. Corporation tax is always higher than income tax so PSCs increase tax
option_c: C. Dividends are taxed as employment income with Class 1 NIC
option_d: D. The client must always operate PAYE regardless of size
option_e: E. Employment allowance can be used to cover the PSC’s employer NIC
explanation: A PSC structure is used because (as self-employed/through company) expenses can be more generous and NIC can be lower; profits may be taxed at corporation tax rates and extracted as dividends (no NIC). Distractors: B[wrong_direction], C[term_confusion], D[exception_as_rule], E[exception_as_rule].

prompt: Where a PSC provides services to a small entity and IR35 applies (per your notes), which statement is correct?
option_a: A. A deemed salary is calculated and the individual is taxed on this (IT + NIC) rather than dividends
option_b: B. The individual remains taxed on dividends and pays no NIC if IR35 applies
option_c: C. Employment allowance can be used to offset employer NIC on the deemed salary
option_d: D. Dividends are taxed twice: once as dividends and again as deemed salary
option_e: E. The client must issue an SDS with a 45-day challenge process
explanation: For small entities (per your notes): a deemed salary is calculated; IT and NIC are paid on the deemed salary, not dividends; employment allowance cannot be used; dividends form part of the deemed salary (so not taxed separately as dividends). Distractors: B[wrong_direction], C[exception_as_rule], D[exception_as_rule], E[same_family].

prompt: For services provided by a PSC to a medium or large entity (per your notes), who determines whether IR35 applies and what document is issued?
option_a: A. The client determines status and issues a Status Determination Statement (SDS)
option_b: B. The PSC determines status and issues an SDS to the client
option_c: C. HMRC determines status and issues an SDS to both parties
option_d: D. The client determines status but no SDS is required
option_e: E. The PSC determines status and issues a 45-day DDP notice
explanation: Per your notes: for medium/large entities, the client determines whether IR35 applies and issues an SDS with reasons; the individual can challenge and the client must respond within 45 days. Distractors: B[term_confusion], C[exception_as_rule], D[exception_as_rule], E[term_confusion].

prompt: Which statement correctly describes SAYE (Save As You Earn) per your notes?
option_a: A. Employees save £5–£500 per month for 3 or 5 years; no IT/NIC on grant/exercise; at maturity they can take cash tax-free or buy shares, with CGT on sale
option_b: B. Selected employees are granted options up to £60,000 which must be exercised 3–10 years after grant
option_c: C. SAYE must be offered only to full-time directors and key employees
option_d: D. SAYE savings must be invested in employer shares throughout the term
option_e: E. SAYE gives CGT-free disposal of shares if held 3 years
explanation: SAYE involves fixed monthly savings (£5–£500) for 3 or 5 years; no IT/NIC on grant/exercise; on completion, cash can be taken with no IT/NIC or shares can be purchased; CGT applies on subsequent sale. Distractors: B[same_family], C[wrong_direction], D[term_confusion], E[exception_as_rule].

subtopic: Employee share schemes (SAYE / CSOP / EMI / SIP)
prompt: For a CSOP (Company Share Option Plan), which rule is correct per your notes?
option_a: A. Options must be exercised between 3 and 10 years after grant
option_b: B. Options may be exercised at any time provided the option price is below market value
option_c: C. Anyone who held over 30% of any company in the last 12 months can participate
option_d: D. Maximum grant is £250,000 per employee
option_e: E. CSOP must be open to all employees on similar terms
explanation: Your notes: CSOP options must be exercised between 3–10 years; shares must be fully paid ordinary; option price at grant must be at least MV; options not transferable; >30% close company holders in previous 12 months excluded; max options £60,000. Distractors: B[wrong_direction], C[exception_as_rule], D[same_family], E[same_family].

subtopic: Employee share schemes (SAYE / CSOP / EMI / SIP)
prompt: Under EMI, when can an income tax (and possibly NIC) charge arise at exercise per your notes?
option_a: A. When shares were issued at a discount to market value at grant; at exercise IT (and NICs if listed) is on the lower of the discount vs MV at exercise, and the price paid
option_b: B. Always at exercise, because EMI options are taxed as employment income
option_c: C. Only if the employee works fewer than 25 hours per week
option_d: D. Only if the company has gross assets above £30m at grant
option_e: E. Never at exercise; only CGT applies regardless of pricing
explanation: Your notes: EMI has no IT/NIC at grant or exercise unless issued at a discount to MV at grant; then at exercise IT (and NIC if listed) is on the lower of discount vs MV at exercise and the price paid. Distractors: B[exception_as_rule], C[term_confusion], D[threshold_swap], E[wrong_direction].
